Summary:
The patient is a 67-year-old male with squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx who presented to the ICU with significant bleeding from the tracheostomy site. The patient underwent coil embolization of the right inferior thyroid artery for a hypopharyngeal bleed, as well as tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement. The patient also has a history of right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and was not an anticoagulation candidate due to recent bleeding. An inferior vena cava (IVC) filter was placed, and the patient is being monitored for signs of pulmonary embolism (PE) or hypoxia. 

The patient has leukocytosis, which could be related to recent events such as bleeding into the oral-pharynx or aspiration pneumonia (APNA). The patient has a history of aspiration pneumonia and is currently on antibiotics. There is also a new right lower lobe infiltrate on chest X-rays, indicating a possible infection. 

The patient's laryngeal cancer is complicated by recent bleeding from the right inferior thyroid artery, which required coil embolization. The patient is scheduled to receive radiation therapy today. 

Other issues include anemia, hyponatremia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and a past cerebrovascular accident (CVA). The patient is currently NPO for a procedure and is receiving IV fluids as needed. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include recurrent bleeding, PE, aspiration pneumonia, and infection due to immunosuppression from cancer and treatment.
